clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacokinetics of Small Spectrum Beta-lactam Antibiotics (Amoxicillin/Clavulanic Acid and Cefuroxime) in Patients on Intensive Care Units
clinical_study.official_title: Pharmacokinetics of Small Spectrum Beta-lactam Antibiotics (Amoxicillin/Clavulanic Acid and Cefuroxime) in Patients on Intensive Care Units

brief_summary.textblock:
Adequate antibiotic therapy is very important in the treatment of infections. Spectrum and dosing of the antibiotics are two factors of the therapy: the spectrum of an antibiotic can't be changed, but the dosing scheme can be optimized. Recent studies proved that an optimized dosing scheme can improve the efficacy of the treatment. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have unpredictable pharmacokinetics in patients on intensive care units. This is due to the pathophysiologic processes in the patients on intensive care units: increased distribution volume, hypoproteinemia, organ failureâ€¦ The investigators guess that similar processes influence the pharmacokinetics of small spectrum antibiotics (like amoxicillin and cefuroxime), but data lacks. Because the pharmacokinetics of broad spectrum antibiotics in seriously ill patients are better known, physicians are more confident prescribing these drugs. Studying the pharmacokinetic interactions of small spectrum antibiotics in seriously ill patients, can help to give the physician the confidence to prescribe these small-spectrum antibiotics.
In this study, the investigators will study the pharmacokinetics of amoxicillin/clavulanic acid and cefuroxime, in 60 patients on intensive care. 8 blood samples will be drawn via a central catheter on different moments after one administration of the antibiotic in the steady state phase. All the patients are prescribed the antibiotics for the treatment of their infections: they get the antibiotic therapy anyway. By measuring the concentrations on different moments after one administration, the investigators can reconstruct the pharmacokinetic function.

primary_outcome.measure: Area under the serum concentration versus time curve (AUC) of Amoxicillin/Clavulanic acid.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and at 15, 30, 45, 60, 120, 240 and 360 minutes after administration
primary_outcome.description: The concentrations of the antibiotic in serum samples, drawn at various times after one administration, will be measured. With these data, we can calculate the time above the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC).

primary_outcome.measure: Area under the serum concentration versus time curve (AUC) of Cefuroxime.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and at 15, 30, 45, 60, 120, 240 and 480 minutes after administration
primary_outcome.description: The concentrations of the antibiotic in serum samples, drawn at various times after one administration, will be measured. With these data, we can calculate the time above the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At date of admission (day 1) and dismissal (up to 3 months).
secondary_outcome.description: This will be assessed using the Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE2)-score.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At date of admission (day 1) and dismissal (up to 3 months).
secondary_outcome.description: This will be assessed using the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score (SOFA-score).
Urine will be collected during 24 hours to measure the urine creatinine clearance.
Change in fluid balance will be measured.

arm_group.description: Patients in the intensive care unit, with an infection which will be treated with Amoxicillin/Clavulanic Acid.
Patients in the intensive care unit, with an infection which will be treated with Cefuroxime.

biospec_descr.textblock: 8 serum samples will be taken per patient.

study_pop.textblock: Patients on the intensive care unit, with an infection (which requires amoxicillin/clavulanic acid or cefuroxime).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients on the intensive care unit, who are treated with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid or cefuroxime for an infection
Exclusion Criteria:
- informed consent lacking
- haematocrit < 21 %
- arterial catheter lacking

clinical_study.keyword: Patients in the intensive care unit, with an infection which requires amoxicillin/clavulanic acid or cefuroxime
